The glass bottom of the bridge is frosted so no worries about those under the bridge looking up & gaining more than they (or you) bargained for. The bridge spans the width of the Sacramento River, the largest river in California. The bridge is a very easy, flat walk suitable for the very young, the elderly, children, & people in both wheelchairs & strollers. On one side of the bridge is Turtle Bay Museum, a fun place for young & old alike. there are interactive live animal shows periodically (check the website for show times) & during certain times of the year a butterfly enclosure & a bird enclosure. Both are fun for people to look close up at winged creatures. Be aware that they may land on you so those who cannot remain calm should opt for other attractions within the museum such as the small aquarium where people can view local fish who live in the river. There are sturgeon, trout, bass, salmon & more for year around viewing. Also inside the museum are changing attractions. Some focus on local Native Americans whereas other focus on animals & feature hands on experiences such as a beaver pelt. The bridge itself is a wonder & was a challenge to situate initially. It had to have a little add-on before it was situated in its current location as it was a few inches short. Across the bridge is river access which is great for summer time as people can dip their feet into the Sacramento River. Right across the bridge & to the left takes people to the botanical gardens which are always being added to. The gardens contain a water feature as well as some sculptures finished by local artists. There is a small coffee/snack shop outside the museum as well as a small seating area. The snack shop offers coffee, juice, water, tea, & some snacks as well as sandwiches which are of generous portions. One is a good size to split between two people.

Designed by Santiago Calatrava and opened on July 4, 2004, Sundial Bridge is a cantilever spar cable-stayed bridge that carries bicycles and pedestrians over Sacramento River in Redding, California. It has become iconic for the city. The pylon that holds up the bridge acts as a sundial, albeit accurate only on summer solstice. Additionally, the bridge connects to the Sacramento River Trail, making it popular among bicyclists.
If you ever have a chance to visit Redding, Sundial Bridge is definitely a must see due to its dramatic appearance. Be sure to bring your cameras or smartphones as you would want to take photos to highlight your visit. And please consider that the deck may be hot, especially on scorching summer days, so always wear shoes if you cross the bridge.

The Sundial bridge is a social center point for the town of Redding and an architectural masterpiece of renowned architect Santiago Calatrava from Spain. It is a great place to start and end walks or jogs along the river. At night it is lit up. During the day you can indeed see the shadow functioning as a Sundial at certain times of the day. Locals love to come here to hang out in the cool evenings. Musicians, street performers, and artistic types as well as new age power absorbers come and spend time on or near the bridge in the evenings. The Turtle Bay museum is close and you can see fishing boats bobbing in the current and fly fishermen wading in the river above and below the bridge. Definitely a place to come for a visit or regular walks.
